awd_titl_txt: Investigation of terminal alkene formation by polyketide synthases and the application toward sustainable alpha-olefin production
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposed Title: Characterization of specific polyketide synthases and application toward the biological production of highly-desirable, short-chain olefins.
	
      	

	Recent concerns as to the supply and cost of petroleum-based fuels and commodity chemicals have sparked an interest in creating alternative routes to these important hydrocarbon compounds. In particular the alpha-olefins, a class of compounds currently derived from petroleum, serve as precursors to many industrially produced plastics, short chain fatty acids, surfactants and recently have been touted as potential fuel alternatives. One potential route for synthesizing commodity and specialty chemicals is to engineer microorganisms to transform inexpensive, renewable sugars to desired products. Unfortunately, the scope of biological transformations available to generate differing chemical functional groups is lacking, thus limiting our ability to replace all petroleum-derived commodity chemicals. In an effort to produce this important set of chemicals, scientists at the University of California, Berkeley have identified enzyme components comprising a class of polyketide synthase (PKS) terminal modules known to generate alpha-olefins by way of a unique structural feature. Understanding the mechanism of this enigmatic reaction will pave the way for future enzyme biocatalyst design, in particular, new designer PKS assemblies for specific terminal alkene production. Studies and engineering efforts concerning the PKS modules will be executed under the supervision of the awardee, Prof. Jay D. Keasling (UC, Berkeley), by a diverse group of students from a wide range of socioeconomic and educational backgrounds. In particular, through the iCLEM program and partnership with the University of California, Berkeley Extension Program, Keasling and his group aim to involve high school and undergraduate students pursuing education outside the formal university requirements (e.g. through Associate Degrees and certificate programs) to gain valuable hands-on experience. 

	The goal of this proposal is to understand how these unique, conserved terminal sulfotransferase-thioesterase (ST-TE) didomains of PKS function to produce alpha-olefins. The specific project aims include 1) to characterize the overall substrate tolerance and fundamental kinetic parameters of four terminal olefin-forming PKS modules; 2) to perform an in-depth mechanistic analysis of the CurM TE to better understand this pivotal transformation; and 3) to use this information to guide the generation of two chimeric synthases for the sustainable production of C5 (pentene) and C6 (hexene) terminal olefins, as well as the related aromatic alkene, styrene. PKS proteins will be expressed in Escherichia coli or a native olefin producer, such as cyanobacteria Synechococcus PCC 7002. Aggregate results will be leveraged to design highly active catalysts specific for producing these olefinic compounds. Chimeric PKSs will be evaluated in both E. coli and Synechococcus PCC 7002 to better explore PKS activity and olefin formation in both natural and unnatural hosts. Definition of this this unique termination mechanism and application of the findings to create novel enzymes will provide a biological route to terminal alkenes, which may ultimately contain novel functional groups (e.g., halogens, amines, etc.) that can be used to create new cross-linkable polymers with altered properties, or compounds with improved fuel characteristics, all from low-cost renewable resources.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
During the course of this project, we engineered polyketide synthases with various load, extension, and termination modules and determined the basic rules of engineering polyketide synthases to produce various short-chain acids, alcohols and alkenes. Specifically, we constructed a number of chimeric PKSs using the lipomycin, avermectin, erythromycin, pikromycin, and niddamycin loading modules; the indanomycin, spinosyn, aureothin, and curacin non-iterating extension modules as well as the iterating borrelidin extension module 5; and several termination modules, including the erythromycin thioesterase and the curacin terminal alkene-forming termination module. We examined solubility and activity of the engineered PKSs both in vitro and in vivo.  We found that BorM5 differentially extends various aliphatic and substituted substrates. Depending on substrate size and substitution BorM5 can exceed the three iterations it natively performs. To probe the effect of methyl branching on chain length regulation we engineered a BorM5 variant capable of incorporating methylmalonyl- and malonyl-CoA into its intermediates. Intermediate methylation did not affect overall chain length, indicating that the enzyme does not to count methyl branches to specify the number of iterations.

One convenient extension substrate for polyketides is allylmalonyl-CoA, which bears a terminal olefin that is constructed via the action of an acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (ACAD). The extender unit is biosynthesized via a polyketide-like pathway in which propionyl-CoA is condensed with malonyl-CoA to form 3-oxo-valeroyl-ACP. The substrate is then reduced to 2-pentenoyl-ACP via the action of the fatty acid synthase of the native FK506 producer. The final two steps of the pathway are catalyzed by an ACAD, TcsD, which oxidizes the γ,δ-position of the extender unit and a crotonyl-CoA reductase/carboxylase, TcsC, which carboxylates the α-carbon to from the malonate extender unit. Original reports (1) suggested that TcsC and TcsD could act interchangeably. However, we hypothesized that TcsD must act prior to TcsC due to the established chemical mechanism of ACAD catalysis. We have shown that indeed, TcsD can only dehydrogenate α,β-unsaturated Coenzyme A-based substrate mimics and does not act on the α-carboxylate substrate, suggesting that the second half of the biosynthetic pathway proceeds in a sequential fashion. 

The PI, graduate students, and post-doctoral fellows supported by this grant were involved in the iCLEM program in all three years of the grant. Each year, 8 economically disadvantaged students from the local community were chosen to spend a 10-week period at JBEI. The students worked alongside two high-school teachers, 2 UCB undergraduate teaching assistants and four scientific JBEI scientific advisors on research projects relevant to the bioenergy field. Students were taught basic skills in microbiology and molecular biology and were mentored in resume writing and college preparation. After the program, students presented their research experience to friends, family and JBEI staff. Most students were ethnic minorities, all are economically disadvantaged. Over the ten-year course of this program, ~95% of the students go on to college and ~80% major in STEM programs.

 

Intellectual Merit: 

The work performed using the funding from this grant allowed us to understand how to exchange domains and modules within PKSs to produce a variety of hydrocarbon molecules.  This will allow us to produce a large number of molecules that heretofore have never been produced using a biological system. 

 

Broader Impact: 

Not only will this work impact the general area of chemical synthesis using microbes, the technologies we’ve developed in the work funded by this grant will allow us to modify antibiotics to produce variants that may be effective where the natural antibiotic is no long effective (e.g., due to resistance). In addition, this work will allow us to produce variants of pest control agents that will be safe to use in the field.

We have educated graduate students, undergraduate students, high school students, and postdoctoral fellows in protein and metabolic engineering. These students are populating universities and companies. Many have chosen to go to college and major in STEM activities due to their participation in our program.

Products:

Publications:

Barajas, J.F., Blake-Hedges, J., Bailey, C.B., Curran, S., Keasling, J.D. Engineered polyketides: synergy between host and protein engineering, Synthetic and Systems Biotechnology, 2017, 2, 147-166

 

Yuzawa, S.; Bailey, C.B.; Fuji, T.; Jocic, R.; Barajas, J.F.; Benites, V.T.; Baidoo, E.E.; Chen, Y.; Petzold, C.J.; Katz, L.; Keasling, J.D. Heterologous Gene Expression of N-Terminally Truncated Variants of LipPKS1 Suggests a Functionally Critical Structural Motif in the N-terminus of Modular Polyketide Synthases. ACS Chem. Biol. 2017, 12, 2725.

 

Eng, C.H.;* Backman, T.W.H.;* Bailey, C.B.; Magnan, C.; García Martín, H.; Katz, L.; Baldi, P.; Keasling, J.D. ClusterCAD: a Computational Platform for Type I Polyketide Synthase Design. Nucl. Acid. Res. 2017, gx893. 

 

Curran, S.C., Hagen, A., Poust, S., Chan, L.J.G., Garabedian, B.M., de Rond, T., Baluyot, M.-J., Vu, J.T., Lau, A.K., Yuzawa, S., Petzold, C.J., Katz, L. and Keasling, J.D. 2018. Probing the flexibility of an iterative modular polyketide synthase with non-native substrates in vitro. ACS Chemical Biology(In press).


Last Modified: 07/30/2018
Modified by: Jay D Keasling
